docs.lead_paragraph: At 7 o'clock on Monday evenings, a tutor comes to Serita Armstrong's Brooklyn apartment, and Ms. Armstrong's 8-year-old identical twins, Nailah and Nabilah, head to the kitchen table and start their lessons. The third graders see their tutor four times a week. Ms. Armstrong, 37, wants a better and bigger life for her twins and their 12-year-old sister, Medina Singletary. She wants them to excel.

headline.main: The Neediest Cases; Despite Struggles, the Goal Is Always to Be Productive

docs.abstract: Serita Armstrong, disabled after fall on job, received assistance from Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies, supported by New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, that allows her to keep home and family intact while she pursues new career; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Verna Eggleston, the departing commissioner of the city’s Human Resources Administration, will leave office with a mixed legacy, advocates for the poor said yesterday. While the number of people who receive food stamps and Medicaid benefits increased substantially under her tenure, they said, she failed to follow through on plans to truly reform the agency.

headline.main: DeBakey Surgery: Not a Case Study (7 Letters)
headline.print_headline: DeBakey Surgery: Not a Case Study

docs.lead_paragraph: The ideals of the Republican revolution of 1994 were always based on a lie.
docs.snippet: The ideals of the Republican revolution of 1994 were always based on a lie.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''The Man on the Table Was 97, but He Devised the Surgery'' (''The Doctor's World,'' front page, Dec. 25): Dr. Michael E. DeBakey's surgery may have been a technical advance of heroic and dramatic proportions, but it was a setback for patients' rights. Dr. DeBakey is the epitome of the informed patient, and a document evidently existed that said he did not want surgery for his disease.

headline.main: DeBakey Surgery: Not a Case Study

docs.abstract: Seven letters comment on Dec 25 article about Dr Michael DeBakey's surgery; Dr David Coppe contends surgery was technical advance but may be setback for patients' rights; Dr Peter J Manos says surgery is emblematic of difficulties of end-of-life care; Dr Fikry B Salib contends concern for legal implications should never handicap doctors from primary focus of saving lives; Dr Allison J Kean praises DeBakey for sharing his story; Joan Noble says case is not representative of what ordinary people deal with in hospitals; Dr Edward Hotchkiss says DeBakey's treatment is evidence of usefulness of advance directives; Dr Daniel J Brauner says case exposes standards of patient autonomy to be impossible ideals; drawing
